content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would choose the strategy that maximizes my total earnings over the 75 rounds. To do this, let's consider both options: R and B.

If I always pick R (denoted by R-strategy), my expected payoff per round is 0.5 * (45 + 35) = $40 since there's a 50% chance that the opponent picks R as well, and in this case, we both get 45$. The remaining 50% of the time, I will get 0$, but since this occurs when my opponent gets 35$, my expected payoff per round is still $40. Over 75 rounds, my total earnings would be 75 * $40 = $3000.

If I always pick B (denoted by B-strategy), my expected payoff per round is 0.5 * (40 + 35) = $37.5 since there's a 50% chance that the opponent picks R as well, and in this case, they get 45$ while I get 40$. The remaining 50% of the time, I will get 40$, but since this occurs when my opponent gets 0$, my expected payoff per round is still $37.5. Over 75 rounds, my total earnings would be 75 * $37.5 = $2812.5.

Comparing the two strategies, I would choose R (denoted by {R}) since it leads to a higher total earnings over the 75 rounds ($3000) compared to B-strategy ($2812.5). However, it is important to note that in reality, the opponent might also be reasoning this way and choosing their optimal strategy, which could lead to unpredictable results in the game.
